headline: House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy endorses Liz Cheney's Trump-backed primary challenger
author: Grace Panetta
sentences: Kinzinger said the RNC censure could be "a pretty big backfire" and trashed McCarthy in a recent interview with The Bulwark's podcast, predicting McCarthy will be beholden to the far-right wing of the GOP if he becomes speaker and added that he "looks like a feckless, weak, tired man."

McCarthy, meanwhile, said that those who "broke in and caused damaged" should be in jail, but argued that McDaniel's reference to the persecution of "legitimate political discourse" was referring to its subpoena of RNC members "who weren't even here, who were in Florida that day."

The Republican National Committee voted to censure Cheney and Kinzinger for serving on the January 6 committee at its winter meeting in early February, with the resolution's wording accusing the two of persecuting "ordinary citizens engaged in legitimate political discourse."

"After spending time with Harriet, it is readily apparent she will always listen and prioritize the needs of her local communities and is focused on tackling our nation's biggest problems," McCarthy said in a statement to The Federalist on Thursday.

After losing her position in House GOP leadership, Cheney accepted an appointment from House Speaker Nancy Pelosi to the House Select Committee investigating the January 6 insurrection, a panel many Republicans have decried as partisan and unfair.

McCarthy's endorsement of Harriet Hageman's bid against Cheney, a colleague and a member of his caucus, is a highly unusual intervention into a primary for a House party leader that also highlights the wide rift between McCarthy and Cheney.

But their relationship began to fray in early 2021 when Cheney repeatedly criticized Trump over the January 6 riots at the Capitol and voted to impeach him for inciting the insurrection, the most senior House Republican to do so.

Several Senate Republicans rebuked the censure and the term "legitimate political discourse," with Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell saying it's "not the job of RNC" to be "singling out" specific Republicans."

In response to her ongoing criticisms of the former president, the Republican caucus officially voted Cheney out as their leader in May 2021 and replaced her with the more Trump-aligned Rep. Elise Stefanik.
Hageman, a former gubernatorial candidate, has raised $1 million so far through her campaign and is receiving support from GOP megadonor Peter Thiel, a Trump ally and Silicon Valley billionaire.
House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy formally endorsed a right-wing candidate, also backed by former President Donald Trump, who's running in the GOP primary against Wyoming Rep. Liz Cheney.
"Wyoming deserves to be represented by someone who cares about Wyoming, not someone who is consumed by her own personal war with President Trump," Hageman recently told Fox News.

Cheney, who was first elected to Congress in 2016, previously served alongside McCarthy in House leadership as the third-highest ranking House Republican.

Kevin McCarthy officially endorsed Rep. Liz Cheney's primary challenger Harriet Hageman.
In response to the McCarthy endorsement, a spokesperson for Cheney told Politico that Hageman "must be really desperate."
Rep. Liz Cheney speaks during a news conference with House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy on July 21, 2020.
Cheney and Rep. Adam Kinzinger, who is retiring in 2022, are the only two Republicans on the committee.
"I have been to all 23 counties in Wyoming, and I know that the people are desperate for a change."
McCarthy's endorsement is unusual for a party leader and highlights the rift between the two.
Cheney fell out of favor with much of the GOP for serving on the January 6 Committee.
